description: On May 4, the gathering ban will be raised to 50 individuals. Preschools and elementary schools, which have operated at a limited capacity, will resume regular operation, and junior colleges and universities will reopen. All schools must limit student groups according to the 50-person limit. UPDATE: On May 4th preschools and elementry schools will resume regular operation and junior colleges and universities will reopen

description: Iceland issues travel ban on non-EU/EEA/EFTA or UK national starting from March 20th
target_geog_level: One or more regional groupings
target_region: Europe,European Union (without the UK),Schengen Area (without the UK),Schengen Area (with the UK),Africa,Asia,ASEAN Countries,North America,Latin America,Central America,Oceania,Middle East
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Starting on June 15, the icelandic government gives arriving tourists three options to chose of. 1. staying in quarantine for 14 days, 2. being screened for the novel coronavirus at Keflavík International Airport
or 3. presenting a certificate of recent screening, approved by Icelandic health authorities. 
The samples will analyzed at the lab of the Department of Microbiology at Landspítali National University Hospital (Reykjavik). Results should be available within five hours. The maximum number of samples taken and analyzed a day is expected to be 1,000. UPDATE: The icelandic government decided to let incoming tourists chose between 3 options for protection against Corona, starting at June15.
target_geog_level: One or more regional groupings
target_region: Europe,European Union (without the UK),Schengen Area (without the UK),Schengen Area (with the UK),Africa,Asia,ASEAN Countries,North America,Latin America,Central America,Oceania,Middle East
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Icelands Chief Epidemiologist and deCODE Genetics start collecting blood samples from the general public in order to help determine how widespread COVID-19 infection has been within the Icelandic population on May 4. Donating blood for the survey is voluntarily. People undergoing blood tests for other reasons will also be asked to donate a sample. The blood samples will also be tested for antibodies. Those, who give blood will be notified of their test results.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As of May 12, Icelands Directory of Health announced that blood samples for anti body tests for Covid-19 are only collected from individuals who come in for blood tests for other reasons. UPDATE: Originally blood samples should be taken from volunteers, now samples are only collected from individuals who come in for blood tests for other reasons.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Iceland launches website on March 13 that informs about Covid-19 containing what one need or want to know about the virus, including how to protect oneself, how Iceland is responding, and special information for tourists
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Iceland announced fines between £360-3590 for violations of the 14-day mandatory quarantine, starting from the 29th of March

description: Iceland enforced a two-week quarantine on all tourists arriving in the country starting on May 24th. UPDATE: Originally only Icelanders and residents of Iceland had to go into quarantine after arriving in the country. Starting with April 24th tourists are no longer exempt from this rule.

description: Iceland sets ut guidelines for restaurants and tour operators from March 14. Restaurants were asked to re-arrange their seating to at least two meters between seats, asking that only families and other groups in regular close contact would be seated together, that menus would be washed between each use, and that hand sanitation be available at entry and encourage guests to use them. Tour operators have been asked to offer hand sanitiser at every entry point and encourage passengers to use them, to use back doors if available, make sure that passengers embark and disembark with enough space in between each, and skip using every other row to ensure proper space between passengers.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Icelands parliament will only address Covid-19 related matters from March 20 to April 20. All meetings related to matters that do not concern COVID-19 will be postponed until later in the year.

description: The Icelandic government announced a ban on gatherings of more than 100 entering into force on the 16th of March.
The Icelandic government modified the number of people allowed at gatherings from 100 to 20 starting on the 24th of March. UPDATE: The limit of people at getherings has been changed from 100 to 20

The Icelandic government has announce fines of up to $360 for those violating the 20 people gathering ban starting from the 29th of March UPDATE: The 20 people limit of gathering is now being enforced through fines

Iceland prolongs the ban on gatherings over 20 people and the closure of schools from April 13 to May 4. UPDATE: Iceland prolongs ban on gatherings and closures of schools from the 13th of April to the 4th of May.

Iceland modified the number of people allowed at gatherings from 20 to 50 starting on May 4th. UPDATE: The Icelandic government modified the number of people allowed at gatherings from 20 to 50 starting on the 4th of May.

The Icelandic government raised the number of people allowed at gatherings from 50 to 200, starting at May 24. UPDATE: Instead of the current limit of 50 people on a gathering Iceland rises the number up to 200 people at gatherings, starting at May 24.
Iceland cancel The Sailors’ Day celebrations in Reykjavik, the event was due to be held on June 7th.
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description: The Icelandic government announced a ban on gatherings of more than 100 entering into force on the 16th of March. The maximum number of people allowed to gather indoors has increased from 200 to 500 people from June 15th to July 5. UPDATE: The maximum number of people allowed to gather indoors has increased from 200 to 500 people from June 15th.

The Icelandic government announced a ban on gatherings of more than 100 entering into force on the 16th of March.  From July 31 gatherings of over 100 people will be banned, this applies to all public spaces, including shops. Children born after 2005 are exempt from this rule. The ban is expected to last until August 13. UPDATE: From July 31 gatherings of over 100 people will be banned instead of 200

Iceland cancels a number of events and festivities over Merchant’s weekend that takes place August 4 to August 6. This as a response to the new COVID-19 restrictions in Iceland, such as Einnar með allur in Akureyri, Sæludaga in Vatnaskógur and Innipúkinn in Reykjavík. Pride, the Skjaldborg Festival in Patreksfjörður and Þjóðhátíð, the annual outdoor festival held in Vestmannaeyjar, have likewise been canceled.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Iceland announced that from August 5 to August 13  there will be no permits given for any sort of entertainment gatherings/events which can be expected to attract groups of people after 23:00.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The festival Culture Night in Reykjavík, Iceland, has been canceled this year due to Covid-19. The event was supposed to take place on August 22.
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of a recreational or commercial event
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description:
The Icelandic government announced a ban on gatherings of more than 100 entering into force on the 16th of March.
UPDATE: The Icelandic government has increased the limitations on mass gatherings from 100 to 200 people, entering into force on the 7th of September 2020. UPDATE: The maximum size of gatherings will be increased from 100 to 200 people on Monday, 7 September 2020.

The Icelandic government announced on September 4 that the maximum number of guests permitted at any one time in swimming pools, bathing
facilities and fitness centres will be raised from 50% to 75% of the numbers permitted under their operating licences. This will come into effect September 7 2020. UPDATE: The previous maximum number of guests permitted in swimming pools, bathing facilities and fitness centers will be raised from 50% to 75% capacity.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Iceland announces that people will have to keep a distance of 2 meters in common areas starting from the 24th of March

The City of Reykjavík offers short-term emergency houses to those who lost their housing due to Covid-19 crisis. This service will be in operation for four months. The emergency housing will be available to people regardless of their legal domicile. They will be allowed to stay in the short-term housing until their case has been channelled to the municipality in which they live.
Iceland allows visitors in nursing homes again starting at may 4th. Only one person will be allowed to visit at a time.

Iceland replaces the minimum distance of 2 meters with a maximum number of 30 riders on buses, starting at May  4. UPDATE: People need to keep a distance of 2 meters in common areas. Starting on May 4 the minimum distance will be replaced for a maximum of 30 riders in buses.
Iceland announce that from July 31 wearing masks will be mandatory on public transport, including planes and ferries. This is expected to be in place until August 13th.
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on ridership of subways and trams
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

The ministry of Health stated on August 5 that face masks shall be used in public transport if the journey lasts longer than thirty minutes. This is expected to be in place until August 13th UPDATE: The first announcement said that you have to wear a face mask when you use  public transport, now you only have to wear a face mask at public transport if the ride is longer than 30 minutes.

description:
Iceland announces that people will have to keep a distance of 2 meters in common areas starting from the 24th of March.
UPDATE: The Icelandic government announces that the original 2 metre social distancing rule has been relaxed to 1 metre. This will take affect on September 7. UPDATE: The ‘social distancing’ rule will be relaxed from the original 2 metre distance to 1 metre.
